Brazil successfully reunites with Portugal after this, and the new state formed in the aftermath of this merges with the Kingdom of Spain to form the Iberian Union, which becomes a puppet of Austria-Hungary. 

. The United States of America falls to a Second American Revolution, lead by anti government militias and disaffected leftists tired of the Zionism of the Republican Party and the fascism of the progressive Democrats. America once again becomes a Constitutional Republic after this, free from the influence of Woodrow Wilson on the left and the neocons on the right. 

. The 1991 coup in Moscow by the Red Army prompts a joint intervention in the Soviet Union by the German, Austrian, Chinese and Japanese Empires, supposedly to restore order. The Soviets, weakened and distracted, are unable to resist and so the USSR quickly falls under the assault. 

. Finland falls to a coup supported by the Germans and becomes a German puppet Kingdom, ruled by the House of Hesse as its imperial family, taking Karlea from Russia during the intervention in the USSR. 

. In the aftermath of the war, Chechnya, Kalmykia and Mariel become puppet kingdoms of the German Empire, while Iden-Ural becomes an Austrian satellite. The Turkic peoples of the USSR gain independence as the Central Asian Federation, a German satellite monarchy ruled by the descendants of the remaining royal houses of the region. 

Outer Mongolia becomes a Khanate ruled by the descendants of Genghis Khan, takes what remains of Inner Mongolia after Mengjiang's restoration, and becomes a Japanese protectorate. Tannu Tuva becomes the Kingdom of Tannu Uriankhai, a Japanese satellite monarchy ruled by a local Mongolian noble family as its monarchs. 

. European Russia becomes the Czardom of Rus, a semi-autonomous part of Sweden ruled by a member of the House of Bernadotte as its Czar. The Czardom takes inspiration from the defunct Russian Republic lead by the Mensheviks and the Russian Federation lead by the fascist White Russian movement that fought the Bolsheviks during the Russian Civil War,  in its governance style and administration.

Chapter 15: A New Age of Empires and the Rebirth of Old Powers

Following the tumultuous Second Xinhai Revolution in the East, the dismantling of the Berlin Wall ignited a series of events that would reshape the political landscape in Europe and beyond. This pivotal period marked the rebirth of several once-extinct empires and kingdoms, resulting in the realignment of global powers and unprecedented geopolitical shifts.

The fall of the Berlin Wall inadvertently led to the restoration of the German Empire of the Kaisers, with the descendants of Hermann Göring assuming the mantle of the imperial family. This unforeseen resurrection was sparked by a previously obscure 1950s US Supreme Court ruling, asserting that the German Empire had never ceased to exist in the eyes of international law following World War I. This revelation paved the way for the German Empire's return to its 1914 borders.

The restoration of the German Empire prompted the activation of the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk, culminating in the reemergence of several German satellite monarchies, including the United Baltic Duchy, the Kingdom of Lithuania, the Ukrainian Hetmanate, the Kingdom of Georgia, and the Kingdom of White Ruthenia in Belarus. These dramatic shifts precipitated the collapse of the Warsaw Pact, the fall of the American-backed dictatorship of Hafez Al-Assad in Syria, and the demise of the Soviet satellite state of Israel.

Subsequently, Jordan annexed Syria, the remnants of Israel, and Palestine to form the Greater Hashemite Kingdom, fostering close ties with Germany and Saddam Hussein's Iraq. The Yugoslav Wars witnessed the return of Austria-Hungary, which regained its pre-WW1 borders and established puppet kingdoms in Montenegro and Serbia. A newly formed Austrian government based its leadership structure on the pre-WW2 Federal State of Austria and Franz Ferdinand's United States of Greater Austria plan. Descendants of Adolf Hitler assumed the title of the ruling imperial family in Vienna.

As part of their expansion, Austria reclaimed Venice and parts of Tyrol from Italy, creating an Austrian puppet kingdom under the Bourbons, with influences from Mussolini's fascist regime. In the wake of the Warsaw Pact's collapse and the activation of the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk, South Africa disintegrated. The Boers managed to establish a Dutch satellite monarchy called "Volkstaat" on the Western Cape, ruled by a Prince of the House of Orange-Nassau. Namibia returned to German control, while the remnants of South Africa became a federation overseen by the Zulu king, who acted as President.

Across the Atlantic, royalists and pro-democracy forces in Mexico overthrew the Institutional Revolutionary Party, reviving the Mexican Empire under the House of Iturbide. As an Austrian protectorate, Mexico conquered Central America and emerged as a regional power. The fall of the military regime in Brazil enabled an alliance between the fascist Integralist movement and pro-democracy forces, resulting in the restoration of the Empire of Brazil, overseen by the House of Orléans-Braganza. The newly reunited Brazil-Portugal and Spain merged to form the Iberian Union, becoming a puppet state of Austria-Hungary.

Meanwhile, the United States witnessed a Second American Revolution, led by anti-government militias and disillusioned leftists frustrated with the politics of the Republican and Democratic parties. The U.S. emerged as a revived Constitutional Republic, free from external influences.

The 1991 coup attempt in Moscow allowed the German, Austrian, Chinese, and Japanese Empires to intervene in the Soviet Union, citing the need to restore order. The beleaguered Soviets capitulated without resistance, and their once-mighty empire crumbled. In the chaos, Finland became a German puppet kingdom, Chechnya, Kalmykia, and Mariel fell under German control, and Iden-Ural became an Austrian satellite. The Turkic peoples of the Soviet Union formed the Central Asian Federation, a German satellite monarchy presided over by regional royal houses.

Outer Mongolia became a Khanate under the control of Genghis Khan's descendants, taking control of the remnants of Inner Mongolia, and becoming a Japanese protectorate. Tannu Tuva emerged as the Kingdom of Tannu Uriankhai, a Japanese satellite monarchy ruled by local Mongolian nobility. European Russia was transformed into the Czardom of Rus, a semi-autonomous territory of Sweden governed by a member of the House of Bernadotte, the Czar of Rus. The Czardom drew inspiration from the Menshevik-led Russian Republic and the White Russian movement during the Russian Civil War in its governance and administration.

The rebirth of these once-dead powers marked the dawn of a new age, characterized by dramatic geopolitical realignments and the resurgence of old empires. This period, marked by both progress and turmoil, forged the modern global landscape and served as a testament to the enduring legacies of these storied nations.

conversations.facetValue: format a series of events from a show into a backstory for a prologue.

allFacetValues.value: format a series of events from a show into a backstory for a prologue.
English
format a given text into a list of main events.

conversation.content:
Delete of the following text words “In the episode X”. Turn the text into the list of the main events but in the past tense.

In Episode 1, King Jaehaerys I Targaryen held a Great Council to choose an heir after both his sons had died. The Westerosi lords selected his grandson, Prince Viserys, over Princess Rhaenys. Nine years into Viserys’ reign, he organized a tournament to celebrate his wife’s pregnancy. However, their baby son died shortly after being born. Viserys banned his brother Daemon from King’s Landing and named Rhaenyra his heir, revealing to her Aegon the Conqueror’s dream inspired him to unify Westeros.

In Episode 2, Daemon illegally occupied Dragonstone, while Rhaenyra suggested showing force against the Triarchy. She appointed Ser Criston Cole to the Kingsguard, and Viserys intended to wed Lady Alicent. Daemon stole a dragon egg and proclaimed himself the true heir, but he renounced it and Viserys announced his intention to marry Alicent.

In Episode 3, Lord Corlys and Prince Daemon battled Craghas Drahar and his pirates for three years without the Iron Throne’s support. King Viserys hosted a great hunt to celebrate his son’s birthday, while Rhaenyra resented the attention towards her half-brother. The king insisted that Rhaenyra must marry for a strong alliance and many suitors were considered. Brothers Hobert and Otto Hightower schemed to make Aegon the successor, while Daemon acted as bait to ambush the Triarchy warriors and won the battle.

In Episode 4, Rhaenyra returned to King’s Landing after an unsuccessful tour to choose a consort. Meanwhile, Daemon returned after conquering most of the Stepstones, now named “King of the Narrow Sea”. After reconciling, Daemon and Rhaenyra sneak out to explore King’s Landing and indulge in drinking, attending a bawdy play, and visiting a brothel. Upon being informed by the White Worm’s spy, the Hand of the King, Ser Otto, told King Viserys about Daemon and Rhaenyra’s carousing. Rhaenyra utilized her position to coerce Ser Criston, and Viserys confronted Daemon, who seemed to confirm the rumors and was exiled to the Vale. To strengthen the throne, Viserys ordered Rhaenyra to marry Ser Laenor Velaryon.

In Episode 5, Daemon murdered his wife and Rhaenyra and Ser Laenor Velaryon were betrothed. Ser Criston killed Laenor’s lover, Ser Joffrey Lonmouth, and Rhaenyra and Laenor were privately wed. Rhaenyra had given birth to three sons, but Viserys rejected the assertion that Laenor was not their father. Alicent began to prepare her son, Aegon, to dispute Rhaenyra’s claim to the Iron Throne.

In Episode 6, Daemon visited Pentos with his wife and daughters and offered them a lordship in exchange for an alliance against a resurgent Triarchy. After an agonizing labor, Laena Velaryon commanded her dragon to incinerate her. Alicent accused Harwin, Rhaenyra’s sworn knight, of fathering her children, and Ser Lyonel Strong escorted him to Harrenhal castle. After they left, Larys, Ser Lyonel’s younger son, recruited three criminals to set a fire at Harrenhal, killing Lyonel and Harwin. Rhaenyra moved to Dragonstone, bringing Laenor’s lover, Ser Qarl Correy.

In Episode 7, King Viserys attends Lady Laena’s funeral while Rhaenyra and Daemon reunite and are physically intimate. Meanwhile, Aemond claims Vhagar as his dragon, causing an altercation in which Lucerys slashes Aemond’s eye. Seeking justice, Alicent attacks Lucerys with Viserys’ Valyrian steel dagger, but Rhaenyra blocks her and gets injured. Viserys decrees anyone questioning Rhaenyra’s sons’ legitimacy will have their tongues removed.

In Episode 8, Lord Corlys Velaryon is severely wounded, and his brother petitions King’s Landing to name him heir, proclaiming Rhaenyra’s son, Lucerys, illegitimate. Rhaenyra and Daemon returned to defend Lucerys’ claim while Viserys is bedridden and disfigured. During a feast, Aemond insinuated that Rhaenyra’s three eldest sons are illegitimate, he fought them. Rhaenyra fled the capital with her family and returned to Dragontone.

Now format it in the form of a prologue to the story or a backstory.

Long before the War of Five Kings, before even the events of the original Game of Thrones, there was another war that threatened to tear the realm of Westeros apart: the Dance of the Dragons.

It was a war fought between two Targaryen siblings, each claiming the throne and the right to rule over their father's kingdom. King Viserys I had named his daughter Rhaenyra as his official heir, but upon his death, his second wife, Alicent, pushed for her son Aegon to take the throne instead.

What followed was a brutal civil war that lasted over two years, pitting dragon against dragon and brother against sister. The events of the Dance of the Dragons shaped the course of Westerosi history and set the stage for the power struggles and conflicts that would come to define the realm for centuries to come.

From the Great Council that named Viserys' heir, to the schemes and battles that ultimately led to the downfall of both Rhaenyra and Aegon, the story of the Dance of the Dragons is a tragic tale of family rivalries, political machinations, and the destructive power of dragonfire.

allFacetValues.value: generate an alternate history scenario with specific events and outcomes.
English
generate an alternate history scenario based on the provided chronological events.

conversation.content:
Write an alternate history scenario in the form of a history book chapter, in which the following events happen in chronological order:

.Yi Sun-sin is killed by the corrupt yangaban of the Yi dynasty occupying the Korean peninsula for his attempted reforms in the Korean navy, resulting in the Japanese shogunate being able to reclaim Korea and defeat the Ming dynasty during the Imjin Wars.

.With the Yi dynasty occupying the Korean peninsula gone and China currently going through a financial crisis, the samurai are able to defeat the Ming Army with ease and force the Chinese Empire to sign an armistice.


.The humiliating nature of the defeat, plus the decadent nature of the Ming Emperors at this point causes a crisis in China that leads to the break up the nation into warring factions, making it easier for the Jurchens for Manchuria to make their move and strike a weakened China, bribing influential commanders and gaining the support of the Chinese people.


. After a disastrous defeat at Nanjing, the Ming dynasty as well as the Imperial Chinese Army and government flee to Vietnam where they create an earlier version of the Dai Viet Empire, conquering Cambodia and Laos and making these nations into satellite monarchies of the Ming government in exile


. Meanwhile, in conquered China, the victorious Jurchens set up court at Beijing and take the Mandate of Heaven for themselves, declaring the formation of the Great Qing Empire and the end of the Chinese dynastical empires.

.Meanwhile in Japan, celebrations break out among both the peasants, nobility and the samurai after the reclamation of the Korean peninsula and the end of the Yi dynasty's occupation of Japanese Korea.


The celebration is also brightened by the fact that the Japanese armies have managed to not only invade mainland China, but defeat the Chinese Armies in battle and force the Chinese Empire to an armistice.


.The remaining Yi dynasty members and the yangaban they helped create flee to Mongolia or Qing-occupied China in vast numbers, as the liberated Korean people hand them over to the samurai sent to remove Chinese influence from Korea and build up the peninsula to the standards of the other provinces of the Japanese shogunate.


.The insane caste system and slavery of the Yi dynasty is abolished in Korea and the old prefectures of Goryeo, Baekje and Silla that had been abolished when Yi-Seon-gye seized power from Daimyo Kōrai Kuyō (Gong-yang in Korean) in 1392 and established the Yi dynasty are restored with shoguns from Japan taking the positions of leadership in these newly restored Korean prefectures of the Japanese shogunate.


.The kisaeng sex slave system and tribute of virgin girls to Ming China that the Yi dynasty used to send is abolished and when the Hangul script is discovered by a loyal Korean retainer, the Japanese then make it the official writing system of the Korean language.


Under the Yi dynasty and their worship of China, Koreans were forced to read and write in either Chinese or write Korean in Hanzi (Chinese letters), that if they could even read.


But now, the Korean people can read and write in their own language thanks to Hideyoshi and his crusade against the Ming dynasty to spread Christianity.


.The Manchu Emperors in Beijing see the good works Hideyoshi and his descendants are doing in Korea after the defeat of China and the fall of the Ming dynasty, and thus recognize that Korea is Japanese territory.


This helps ease relations between the Qing and feudal Japan.

.In Indochina, the Ming Emperors lament the loss of mainland China and the fall of their loyal ally in the Yi dynasty but also realize they need to modernize and reform.


With the Laotians and Khmer subdued and the crypto-Muslim nature of the Ming dynasty helping them to control the other nations of Indochina, the Dai Viet sends students to the Ottoman Empire and Mughal India to try and learn as much as they can to catch up with the rest of the world.


The knowledge these students brings back allows the Ming Emperors to modernize the Dai Viet and also combine Chinese dynastic rule with Muslim sharia law governance and European ideals of monarchy inspired by the pre-rennissance era in European history.


As time passes, the Ming Empire in exile in Vietnam becomes less of a Chinese dynasty in Indochina and more of a Vietnamese nation state, with the House of Zhu that rules the Ming dynasty as its imperial family becoming the Ngyuen dynasty of Vietnam as time passes

.But Japan will not become the dominant power in the world until the second world war against the British and French Empire, and only then its unipolarity will not come until the fall of the Canadian Empire under the Windsors in 1991 to pro-democracy rebels.


For the moment, the Tokugawas refrain from foreign adventures after the passing of Hideyoshi's heirs and instead uneasily watch European colonialism in Asia.


Although the Japanese are initially suspicious of the Qing Empire, tensions between the two nations ease after the Manchu Emperor hands over Taiwan to Japan and recognizes Japan as the ruler of the Korean peninsula.


The Qing also recognize the Japanese as the rightful holders of the Mandate of Heaven due to the Tang dynasty of China's suspicious similarities to the primordial Japanese Empire before the rise of the first shogun.


.With limited Japanese help, the Qing spread firearms technology and combined arms warfare to their homeland of Manchuria and start a minor industrial revolution in conquered China, breaking the power of the Han nationalists who wish to bring the Ming dynasty back and expel the Manchu by offering jobs and employment to the starving Chinese masses.


As a result, the Han loyalists and Ming supporters remaining in China migrate to Vietnam which is ruled by the Ming Emperors, removing a major source of tension in China.


.The Qing also send scholars and young noblemen to the universities of the Ottoman Empire and the Austrian-dominated Holy Roman Empire, seeing these two nations of the world as the major world powers. 


The knowledge these people bring back allows the Qing to modernize their Empire and conquer Mongolia and East Turkestan, the Qing also form relations with the Mughal Empire before the British conquest of the Indian subcontinent.


.Fearing that England will try and break up the Qing Empire and conquer Manchuria the same way the UK did to Mughal India, the Manchu Emperors and feudal Japan support the Thirteen Colonies in their war of independence against the British Empire, Japanese arms and mercenaries combined with the wealth of the Qing Empire turning the tide against the British.


This leads to Japan and the Americans having the same relationship the US and the KMT had in our timeline.


.The Hapsburgs then integrate the USA into their Empire as another of their New World colonies, although with a fair deal of autonomy. They also deport most of the Tories and British loyalists to Canada or England, removing a source of tension for the Americas.

Chapter XI - The Shifting Tides of Asia

In the late 16th century, the assassination of famed Korean admiral Yi Sun-sin, perpetrated by the corrupt yangaban of the Korean Yi dynasty, set in motion a profound and substantial reordering of the balance of power in East Asia. It was the first in a series of events that would ultimately result in the rise of the Japanese Shogunate as the preeminent power in the region, the fall of the Ming dynasty and the eventual fragmentation of China, and the establishment of new empires across the continent, with lasting repercussions.

The Imjin Wars: The Japanese Shogunate Ascendant

Following Sun-sin's death, the Japanese Shogunate was able to reclaim the Korean peninsula, dealing a heavy blow to both the Korean Yi dynasty and their Chinese Ming allies. The Ming dynasty, already weakened by financial crisis, was no match for the samurai forces. In short order, the Chinese Empire was forced to sign an armistice, ceding control of the Korean peninsula and dealing a major blow to China's regional hegemony.

The Fall of the Ming Dynasty and Rise of the Qing

The humiliating nature of China's defeat, coupled with the decadence of the Ming Emperors, plunged China into a crisis that led to the country fracturing into warring factions. The Jurchens of Manchuria capitalized on this chaos, allying with influential Chinese commanders and gaining popular support in their incursions into China. The eventual fall of Nanjing to the Jurchens effectively marked the end of the Ming dynasty.

The Ming Empire in Exile in Indochina

With their homeland lost, the remnants of the Ming dynasty fled to Vietnam, establishing an early version of the Dai Viet Empire. From there, they expanded their control over neighboring Cambodia and Laos, creating satellite monarchies under the watchful eye of the Ming government in exile.

The Rise of the Qing Empire

In the vacuum left by the vanquished Ming, the victorious Jurchens established their court in Beijing, proclaiming the formation of the Great Qing Empire and marking the end of the Chinese dynastical era. This newfound power in Beijing would, in time, radically reshape the geopolitical landscape of East Asia.

Japan Triumphs

The Japanese, meanwhile, were ecstatic at the prospect of having liberated the Korean peninsula from the clutches of the Yi dynasty, which had long treated Japan as a tributary state. With the elimination of the Yi dynasty, Japan set about modernizing Korea, abolishing the caste system and instituting reforms aimed at better integrating the peninsula into the Japanese Shogunate.

The Transformation of the Ming Emperors into the Nguyen Dynasty of Vietnam

As the Ming Emperors ruled Vietnam and the surrounding territories from their exiled court, the nature of the Dai Viet Empire gradually shifted away from traditional Chinese dynastic leadership to a Vietnamese state with the mingling of Chinese, Indochinese, and Muslim influences in governance and culture. Thus, the House of Zhu eventually became the Nguyen dynasty of Vietnam.

The Power Dynamics Shift in East Asia

The 17th and 18th centuries saw the Qing Empire and Japan grapple over the fate of their respective corners of the world, with each positioning themselves as the rightful heirs to the Mandate of Heaven, but tensions would eventually thaw over time. The shared fear of European colonialism and their mutual antipathy towards the British Empire in particular drove the two powers into uneasy cooperation as they sought to modernize their nations, expand their influence across the continent and, indeed, the globe.

In the centuries that followed, these transformations would have profound and far-reaching consequences, shaping the course of world history through the shifting fortunes of these great nations. As European powers made inroads into Asia, and the United States emerged as a global player, the tapestry of alliances, rivalries, and cultural exchange that defined Asian geopolitics would be forever altered. And it was all initiated by the assassination of Yi Sun-sin, an event that seemed, at the time, to be of little consequence, yet would ripple through the ages as a catalyst for profound change.

conversation.content:
Write a riveting, interesting play-by-play alternate history scenario in the form of a history book chapter, where the following attempts occur in chronological order:


.Ambitious Korean general Yi-Seong-gye, dies under mysterious circumstances in 1388, preventing the formation of a united, independent Korean kingdom and causing the so-called 'three kingdoms' of Goguryeo, Baekje, and Silla on the Korean peninsula to remain provinces of the Japanese shogunate, ruled by daiymou and paying fealty to the House of Yamato and the imperial court in Kyoto like any other Japanese province on the Japanese Home Islands.


.The Korean language of course still exists and the Hangul script is still created in 1443, to give the Koreans their own writing system, but Korea itself has a status akin to Okinawa in modern Japanese history, with the Korean language being considered as a dialect of Japanese and the Korean people being considered a sub-section of the wider Japanese nation, with their own unique writing system and dialect.


.The Ming dynasty itself, along with Han Chinese loyalists and the bulk of the Imperial Chinese Army, flee to Indochina after the fall of the Chinese Empire to the Jurchen tribes in Manchuria in 1644 and quickly overthrow the native Le dynasty of Vietnam, establishing the Empire of Dai Viet as a Chinese government in exile.


.The Empire of Dai Viet conquers the Khmers and the Laotians and establishes Cambodia and Laos as satellite kingdoms under the protection of the Ming imperial government in Vietnam.

.Over time, the House of Zhu that rules the Ming dynasty as its imperial family becomes the Ngyuen dynasty of Vietnam, and the Empire of Dai Viet becomes the foundation for a modern Vietnamese nation-state.

. Both the Great Qing Empire and the Empire of Dai Viet begin sending young nobles to study in the Austrian-dominated Holy Roman Empire and the Turkish Ottoman Sultanate, believing that they need to gain as much information and knowledge as they can about the world outside Asia. The knowledge these expirates bring back to their countries sparks an industrial revolution in the Qing Empire and a golden age in Dai Viet and its satellite states. 

. The Kingdom of Prussia claims the British Caribbean colony of Jamaica, as well as the Jamaican overseas possesions of British Honduras [Belize], the Turks and Caicos and the Cayman Isles during the last days of the Napoleonic Wars. The Prussians end chattel slavery and institute religious freedom after taking these territories from the British.  

. The German Empire is formed in 1848, after Austria leaves the German Confederation that replaces the Holy Roman Empire. The Germans manage to take the Sudetenland from Austria, and annex Luxembourg and the Netherlands into their nation. 

. The Kings of Prussia become the Kaisers of Germany, and Germany begins to undergo a period of rapid growth and development. 

. A young boy named Woodrow Wilson dies in the last days of the American civil war, denying the ruling Democratic Party of the Confederacy and its later street arm, the KKK the opportunity to place a charismatic frontman for their racist, destructive agenda in the White House. 

. Soon after, the USA and Mexico become colonies of the Austrian Empire, along with Venezuela. The Hapsburgs use the Reconstruction period as an excuse to launch a brutal crackdown on all Anglophile and pro-English elements within the United States, and remodel the United States into the Colombian Federation, with a Hapsburg sub-branch becoming the American imperial dynasty. 

. The Meiji Restoration of 1868 is a compromise between the liberal reformers who wish to restore the imperial system and the nobles and samurai who want to preserve the social order of the feudal shogunate. In the end, the emperors of Japan regain their executive power and an electoral system of free and fair, multiparty elections is established, but the Tokugawa clan retains its position as the shoguns of Japan. 

. The position of Shogun is modified to be something akin to the Ministerpräsidents of Germany and the Austrian Empire after the Meiji Restoration. 

. Japan still takes Okinawa as a prefecture in 1879, and turns the Pengu Islands and Taiwan into the prefecture of Formosa after taking them the Treaty of Shimonoseki in 1945, but restores the Kingdom of Tungning ruled by the Zheng dynasty as the government of Taiwan. Real power in Taiwan lies in the hands of the Govenor-General. 

. The German Empire defeats the fascist regime of the Second French Empire under Napoleon III in November 1871, taking Alsace-Lorraine and forcing the French to pay repatriations. The supposedly democratic Third French Republic is formed, but crypto-fascist groups and the royalist group turned secret society, the enigimatic Action Française still hold influence in France and manipulate French society from behind the scences. 

. The Empire of Japan never signs the Anglo-Japanese alliance and instead joins the Central Powers as an unofficial member after Emperor Franz Josef of Austria allows the Japanese and the Colombian Federation joint management of the colony of the Philippines after domestic instability rocks Austria's satellite state of Spain. 

. With the help of its fellow democratic monarchies in the Central Powers, Japan defeats the Russian Empire in 1907 and forces the Russians to relinquish Sahlakin Island, which Japan promptly takes as a province. The French and British, along with Russia are forced to recognize Japanese control of Sahlakin and Japanese railway rights in Manchuria, the homeland of the ruling Manchus of the Great Qing Empire.

. WW1 breaks out in 1911 over the Morocco Crisis, just as the Xinhai Revolution against the Great Qing Empire is breaking out. The Japanese help the Qing Emperor Pu Yi and the Qing government to escape to Manchuria, which becomes a Japanese protectorate. East Turkestan, Tibet and Mongolia become independent from the Qing Empire and become Japanese satellite states.  

. The Japanese join the Great War on the side of the Central Powers, helping the Marquis of Extended Grace, Zhu Yuxuan, to rise thorugh the ranks of the Republic of China and eventually be coronated as Ming Emperor in 1912, restoring the Chinese Empire that had ended in 1644. Some elements of the ROC's government remain in the restored Ming dynasty, but the Japanese reorganize China into a federation of its core provinces. 

. Due to Austrian control of North America and Japan dominating the Pacific, the Entente is cut off from its colonies and eventually collapses in 1914. 

. The British Isles are divided into the German puppet states of a united Irish kingdom, the Kingdom of Scotland, the Dutchy of Wales, the Principality of Cornwall, and the Kingdom of England.

. The Dutchy of Brittany and the Kingdom of Occitania are liberated from French occupation and become German satelites. France becomes a German puppet kingdom under the Bourbons. 

. The treaty of Brest-Litosk is recognized as valid by the English and French kingdoms, providing legitimacy to the satellite states and puppet monarchies the Central Powers have set up in the Baltics, Eastern Europe and the Caucuses after the fall of the Russian Empire.

. The Central Powers intervene in the Russian Civil War after the fall of the Russian Empire and defeat both the Bolsheviks and White Russians, German puppeting Novorgod, Mari-El, Kalmakiya and Chechnya as satellite kingdoms while the Austrians puppet Iden-Ural. Japan sets up the Far Eastern Republic on the Russian East Coast and puppets Siberia as a confederation of native tribes. 

. European Russia becomes the Czardom of Rus, ruled by Austria as a satellite state with a branch of the Hapsburgs as its imperial family. 

. Germany seizes all of the Entente colonies in sub-Saharan Africa and forms Mittelafrika, while South Africa is reorganized into a federation ruled by a member of the Dutch House of Orange Nassau as its king. 

. The Colombian Federation annexes most of Canada and the Entente's Caribbean colonies, with the Mexican Empire taking Central America. Venezuela takes most of Guyana. Quebec is liberated as an Austrian puppet kingdom, ruled by the House of Orleans.

. Japan establishes puppet states in the Entente's colonial holdings in East Asia and Oceania and forms the Greater East Asian Co-Prosperity Sphere to help rebuild Asia after years of colonial rule and exploitation,

. The victory of the Central Powers over the Entente marks the triumph of liberal democracy over fascism, autocracy and feudalism.

.

Chapter 7: A World Reimagined - The Triumph of Liberal Democracy

The year 1914 marked a turning point not just in the history of Europe, but the entire world. The fall of the old European order - the defeat of the once-mighty Entente by the Central Powers - led to the establishment of a new order, one shaped by a commitment to liberal democracy and thrones forever tied by blood to one another. This chapter will delve into the world that was redefined by a series of ambitious military and political maneuvers, illustrating a history that stands as a testament to the power of unity and the shaping of fortune.

The first and arguably the most significant change in the wake of these events was the continuation of the three Korean kingdoms - Goguryeo, Baekje, and Silla - as Japanese shogunate provinces. The untimely death of Yi-Seong-gye in 1388 prevented a united Korea and changed the course of East Asian history. The Korean language continued to evolve, though now regarded as a dialect of Japanese, and with the 1443 creation of the Hangul script, Korea's status mirrored that of Okinawa in modern Japanese history.

Following the collapse of the Ming dynasty in China, remnants of the imperial court and army found refuge in the newly formed Empire of Dai Viet. With the overthrow of the Le dynasty in Vietnam, the lands of Indochina were conquered in rapid succession, giving rise to satellite states, Cambodia and Laos. As the House of Zhu assimilated into Vietnamese nobility, the strata of imperial legacy woven through the nation was set anew.

As knowledge and understanding spread between nations during the age of exploration, young nobles from both the Qing Empire and the Empire of Dai Viet embarked on a quest to learn from the great powers of Europe. Their discoveries led to an industrial revolution that forever changed the trajectory of the traditional East Asian societies.

Meanwhile, in the Caribbean, the ambitious Kingdom of Prussia seized British colonies of Jamaica, Belize, and the outlying archipelagos. With the subsequent abolition of slavery and the granting of religious freedom, the region embarked on a path towards peace and prosperity.

Europe saw tremendous change during this period, with the formation of the German Empire in 1848, the incorporation of neighboring territories, and the ascension of the Prussian royalty to the position of Kaiser. The death of the charismatic Woodrow Wilson paved the way for a less reactionary era, preventing the United States and Mexico from falling under Austrian rule.

The Meiji Restoration in Japan struck a delicate balance between the demands of the liberal reformers and the conservatives by maintaining the imperial family's executive power and introducing a democratic electoral system. The position of Shogun was transformed into a Ministerpräsident-like role, setting Japan on a path of rapid modernization and political stability.

Apart from political reformation, territorial expansion in the Pacific seemed a natural progression for the Japanese Empire. Having already subjugated the Pengu Islands and Taiwan, Japan successfully annexed Okinawa in 1879, cementing its position as a regional superpower.

With the rise of imperial Japan came the decline of the French and British empires in Europe. Numerous territories changed hands, new puppet states were established, and the continent underwent extensive reorganization under the leadership of the Central Powers.

This incredible shift in power also significantly affected the United States of America, where the Austrian Empire took control during the tumultuous Reconstruction period. Known as the Colombian Federation, this territory expanded to include much of Canada, the Caribbean, and parts of South America, all administered by a branch of the Hapsburg family.

As Japan continued to expand its sphere of influence throughout Asia, it established the Greater East Asian Co-Prosperity Sphere aimed at rebuilding the diverse nations that had suffered under years of colonial rule.

In conclusion, the remarkable series of events that led to the victory of the Central Powers not only reshaped the world but raised the flag of liberal democracy in triumph. This alternate history bears the marks of both great heroes and tragedies, illuminating a complex patchwork of nations forever intertwined by a shared past and an uncertain future.

conversation.content:
Please critically review Chapter 4 of the following text:

WEIRD DREAMS

Chapter One

Day broke over Plymouth, bringing a slow grey sky, damp morose streets and damp morose milkmen, finished off by a minor surge in the electricity supply as quarter of a million clock radios turned on to the early morning show.

Waking up is hard to do, thought Steve. Radio playing, birds singing, Monday morning. He sighed, turned over, and without opening his eyes hit the radio right on the snooze button. That'd teach it. Another five minutes wouldn't hurt...

But radios are made of sterner stuff. Five minutes later, unbowed by such early morning violence, it resumed its unspeakable pop. Which turned, in time, unto unpalatable news. Yawn... He really should get up now, or he'd have to run for the bus again. Strange - his usual warm sleepiness was mixed with something else...

Two records after the news. He really had to get up now. Least disgusting pair of boxer shorts, that shirt would do for today, and into the bathroom to shave his teeth... breakfast, paper and irresponsible TV weathermen later, Steve had diagnosed his problem.

He was feeling a bit peaky, as his mum would've said had she not been living in North Dakota. Nothing worse than that. Still, Steve mused, perhaps he was coming down with the flu. Perhaps he ought to get something for it. To really get Monday going, among the junk mail was a note from his dentist reminding him of his six-monthly checkup. Which was, he noticed, tomorrow. Super.

He ran for the bus, went upstairs and he read the paper, then trudged the ten minute walk from stop to work. Wet pavements and grey skies - it wasn't actually raining, but that was only a matter of time - did nothing to remove his malaise. In the office, he mentioned his lack of well-being to Emily, a bright girl in the postroom he'd got his eye on. He had often wondered whether he should ask her out but, just as often, decided not to. Never know, keep the friendship going and who knows what might happen? He'd never noticed, which was a bit insensitive on his part, that Emily was bored with life. More importantly, and this really wasn't his fault, he'd never noticed that she was a bored daemon. One of those mythical creatures who spend their eternal lives pushing misery, evil and discord.

Emily hadn't started out as a daemon, few people do; her body had been possessed by the spirit Zelloripus as she waited out her punishment. Three thousand years ago, Zelloripus had been banished from the Central Circle of the court of Asklarioum in Chael for a crime against fellow daemons. A crime so despicable that, had it worked, she would have challenged the Great One herself.

Given human form and stripped of many of her daemonic powers, she was sent to live the life of a mortal being on one of the less pleasant planets, Earth. As each host body died, she hopped into a new one, taking over the mind and feeding on the soul. Three thousand years into her sentence, with three thousand more to go, she was not happy. Sixty centuries in Plymouth is enough to embitter anyone. Even one whose residual evilness could, if focussed, melt a toddler's ice cream from a distance of ten miles.

Today there were many puddles of Guiseppi's Famous Italian Ice Cream on the pavements of Plymouth. For today was special. Exactly half-way through Zelloripus' exile, she was feeling mean and ornery and disposed to high mischief. She despised the humans whose form she took; they by and large achieved oblivion in just seventy short years. She especially despised Steve, whose somnolent form sonorously snoring through lunchbreaks was a continual reminder of a contented peace of mind denied her.

Daemons don't sleep; chances are that Another lurks nearby with designs on their soulstuff. A diabolic doze is the best they can normally manage; even this is denied those cast out of Hades because of the forces of Good that are on constant watch. Even, it had to be said, in Plymouth, where three thousand years of sleepless nights and boring days were driving Zelloripus close to breaking point. So far, she'd stuck to the rules, because using what remained of her powers to tamper with mortal affairs could double or treble her stay on Earth. But only if she was detected; the temptation to lash out at something or someone was growing. Her current job, with Plymouth's third most succesfful producer of soap, was not helping things.

So mere bad timing could explain Steve's unhappy encounter with Zelloripus, or Emily as she should be called, on this day in particular. Maybe it was just bad luck that accounted for the copious yawns, heavy eyelids and sleep-slurred voice with which he laced the conversation over her franking machine. But the following conversation was almost too bad to be true...

"Hiya Emily," said Steve. "You're looking wide eyed for a Monday morning. Wish I could be so awake, but I've been in bed most of the weekend."

"Poor soul." said Emily, "What's the matter?"

"Oh, I dunno. Think it's a touch of the flu; all I can do is sleep. It was a real effort to get up today. You don't know of anything that could perk me up a bit, do you?"

Emily, bitter from boredom, was close to the edge. "No," she said "I don't usually get that sort of problem. With sleeping, I mean."

It was probably his attempt at humour, or maybe it was a particularly clumsy chat-up line, that did it. "Perhaps you should sleep with me - it would maybe rub off a little. There's nothing like a good night's kip to make your fellow man seem a bit nicer..."

"I'm sure" said Emily with a smile so sharp it was opening the letters, "that you're right there. Tell me, Steve, do you dream?"

"Dream? No, can't say that I do. Not that I remember, that is. But if I did, it would be of you."

"How sweet. Perhaps I can help you, at least" and here the smile was diamond-tipped "with the flu. I think I might just have something in my handbag. Hold on, let me go and get it."

Steve was pleased. It might be worth asking her out after all, let's see, there's the funfair out of town... no, she's too bright for that... Outside, the weak sunlight darkened for a moment, as if a cloud had passed.

She came back. "Here we are, something I got from a drug store last time I had the flu." It was a small brown bottle, with an indistinct label and, just visible in the powdery interior, three white pills. "You're supposed to have them before a meal, just take the lot tonight with a bottle of red wine and some cheese and you'll be a new man."

"Thanks very much, Emily" said Steve, taking the bottle from her hand. "I'll do that. Look, what are you doing this weekend? Do you fancy a trip to see the new Stallone film or something?"
"I'm not sure" lied the being with three thousand years' worth of identical Plymothian weekends stretched out in front of her. "Let's see how you're feeling in a couple of days. Wouldn't want to over-exert you during your convalescence".

"Oh, I'm sure I'll be fine. I don't think I'll change my mind!"

"We'll see" said Emily, allowing just a hint of cold, evil-tinged boredom to slip out.

That evening, Steve wondered about Emily's last words. There was something not quite right, he decided, and came to a similar conclusion about the thrice-microwaved chilli con carne sitting in a bowl in the fridge. Then he remembered that wine and cheese had been recommended, and, although he was feeling fine by now, he thought that taking the lady's medicine followed by a triumphal Tuesday morning could do no harm. He had the cheese, and trotted out to the nearest 7-11 to get a bottle of red wine.

Back at home, he emptied the three pills out of the bottle into his hand. Nothing special, thought he, and with a flourish popped them into his mouth and washed them down with a long draft of Burgundy. The cheese sandwich followed. A quick scan of the TV pages - why is there never anything on a Monday night? - convinced him of the desirability of bed.

It's not generally appreciated that much magic is real, test-tubed and white-coated, science. Merlin's laboratory technique would have brought murmurs of approval from Pasteur, and watching Shiva smite (from a safe distance) might well have enlightened Einstein still further. It's just that while the great unwashed mass of men were more interested in squabbling, sex and smallpox it contented the Immortals to hide their rational prowess behind a web of mystic mishmash.

Sure, there is magic to be had, but using it brings many repercussions which might not be completely controllable. Many magicians had lost their souls in the long research programme which, although almost half as old as the Universe, was still not producing results. But boy, was it over budget. Some of its more spectacular failures were still puzzling astronomers from a thousand worlds; more than few of whom were unexpected by-products from an experiment or two themselves.

Emily was especially wary of employing the Dark Art. Not only had it landed her in this mess in the first place, but its use could signal loud and clear her position to any number of undesirable companions from the busybodies at Asklarioum, or something far more sinister. As it was, materialising the pills had been risky enough. Her excellent knowledge of human biochemistry helped her from there.

As Steve dropped off to sleep, the pills were lying inert in his stomach. Slowly the gastric acid ate away the outer case, and the compounds within began to diffuse out. And what compounds, the like of which had not been seen on Earth before or (it is safe to assume) since. Any chemist worth his NaCl would have given his spatula to have been in on the action.

First, the long chain molecules from the cheese were broken down to several interesting substances. The alcohol from the wine helped carry these and others from the pills themselves to the stomach wall, through which they slipped like Mexicans into Texas. On the other side of the wall, the usual gang of enzymes were waiting to digest the evening meal; but they weren't ready for what came at them. The scene of chemical carnage was brutal but short.

Past the first stage of digestion, the intruding substances reached the blood stream. Dissolved in the plasma, they drifted up until they got to Steve's brain. The blood brain barrier - that wonderful filter that keeps hunks of pizza molecule out while letting oxygen in - was as effective as a traffic cop against a battalion of Soviet tanks. Emily's dark designs began their invidious work.

Steve's brain was defenceless against the chemical onslaught. The vast, and mostly unused, network of neurones lay in front of them. Even as the last molecules were arriving, the compounds got to work. They diddled the dopamine receptors, they speeded up the cortical synapses, they nobbled the noradrenaline. A thin web of complex bonds spread deep into Steve's cerebellum, like frost over a tree. Further and further they went, until every part of his brain was invaded and controlled. For the moment they did nothing, but somewhere else in the Plymothian night a small chuckle of anticipation bounced off the flock wallpaper. In his sleep, Steve stirred and shivered.

Chapter 2

The next day, Steve woke up, as usual, to the clock radio. Unusually, he found himself listening to it, and, even more strangely, it annoyed him. He turned over in bed and thumped the switch, leaving the bedroom to the birds, noisy Fords and myriad other sounds of morning. He stared at the ceiling. Hangover? No, he'd only had a couple of glasses of wine last night. Anyway, his head didn't hurt and he felt all right, sort of, except... He was wide awake. That was odd, too, as most days he only started to really wake up on the bus into work.

He glanced at the clock radio; he still had a good half-hour until he had to leave, so he tried to doze. As he closed his eyes, the world spun. About fifteen years ago, he'd gone to Scotland with his parents, and once he'd crawled up to the edge of a granite cliff and peered over at the rocks and sea hundreds of feet beneath. He remembered amazement, awe and no little fear, but most of all he remembered the spiralling vertigo. That was what he was feeling now - he gripped the sides of the bed and opened his eyes rapidly, sweating.

The flu? Those pills he took last night? Could be, but he'd never been ill like that before, nor taken anything from a chemist that shook him up so badly. For a moment he was worried, but then the morning took over again, and the sound of a bus pulling up the hill reminded and reassured him that another normal day was waiting. He got out of bed and, standing up, felt fine once more. The coffee and eggs of breakfast tasted really good, but he didn't feel like reading his paper on the bus. For some reason, he wasn't interested in "Rock Star Eats Own Hand, Sells Guitar", which seemed to be the most earthshaking intelligence on offer. Back in the office, he homed in on Emily.

"Hey, Emily" he said "Those pills seemed to have done the trick. No flu, not a sniffle. I'm feeling really awake. They're good stuff - what're they called? I'd like to get some, just for next time, you know?"

She giggled, a short, high-pitched stutter like a pony neighing. "Glad they seem to have worked, Steve. I can't remember their name, though, I've had them for a while. Still, if it comes back to me I'll let you know."

"You've usually got such a good memory, Emily" said Steve ingratiatingly. "Me, mine's like a sieve. Can't even remember things like buying milk or doctor's appointments. Oh no!"

"What's up?" asked Emily, wondering for a moment whether she'd miscalculated something and wondering, just for a moment, what exactly she'd done. Just for a moment, and then she realised. "Forgotten an appointment?"

"Dentist. What's the time? Look, I've got to rush. See you at lunch - if I've got any teeth left" And he dashed into the boss' office to explain his impending absence.

He rushed out of the building. His dentist was about a half a mile away, and by walking fast he could make it. Past the bombed church in the roundabout, past the police station, up the hill, past the library, past the reservoir and into Dr V. Sells, known since childhood as Dr Weasel. The receptionist looked through her window - hello <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_PERSON>, hello Mr Trevathen take a seat he's running a little late - and he dived into the piles of House and Garden from 1972.

Back in the office, the morning post had been sorted and distributed, and there was, as usual, half-an-hour's hiatus before the pre-lunch mailbags came in. Jill went out to round up all the outgoing mail from the seven floors, leaving Emily to herself. She checked her watch, and felt the sea of infinite boredom recede a little. Any minute now, and the first part of her plan would start to work.

Deep within Steve's brain, profound changes were taking place. The tendrils of diabolic chemistry insinuated into his hippocampus, a small lump of grey matter normally concerned with sorting Steve's experience (such as they were) into long-term recall, and started to subtly rewire his memory mechanisms. Large portions of his mind were converted into the biological equivalent of RAM; ready to record experiences and, having recorded them, control his mind as a program controls a computer's processor. Elsewhere similar changes were taking place, but for now things were ready just to record. Just for now.

The triggers to load the program were complex. If Steve was interested, then whatever it was that held his interest would be sorted, stored, activated. If he was frightened, amused, intrigued, it would all be recorded. But for this to work, he had to be capable of taking an interest in the first place. So part of Emily's chemical mishmash sharpened his wits, heightened his awareness, upped his IQ to just short of genius. This, she thought, was a nice move. Not only did it ensure that the data recorded would be powerful and particularly apt, but when the second stage began he would be only too capable of, mmmm, appreciating what was happening to him. He might even fight back, which would round off the whole thing nicely. And, she though with a daemonic delight, it would serve him right to be given a glimpse of what it's like to have an intelligence confronted with infinite boredom.

Steve was, as the plan demanded, unaware of the mental mayhem crystallising beneath his cranium. But he was getting painfully aware of a lot of other things as he sat in the formica and chipboard waiting room. The posters of rabbits noshing carrots and jaunty poems about plaque ("Clean Clean Clean your teeth! Or else the germs get underneath!") were fading and a couple flapped loose at the corners. They'd been there since he'd started seeing Dr Weasel, and, he mused, the place probably hadn't seen a touch of paint for ten years before that.

The bright orange and grey polypropelene bucket chairs finished of a fine example of early 'sixties public health design. Now why did he think that? He'd been here every six months for years, and usually only worried about whether he'd get a filling or not. Those old magazines - did people really think that the ideal home looked like that? The clothes they wore in the photos looked laughable too, but he could remember when he'd thought they looked good. How strange... perhaps the jacket and jeans he was wearing now would be equally ridiculous in ten years time.

The buzzer chainsawed its way into his daydreams, and the receptionist looked up. "Mr Trevathen?". He stood up, and went into the surgery. Dr Sells was shuffling through some papers at a desk, and the Chair sat in the middle of the room beneath the usual battery of technology.

"Hello Steve", said the dentist. "Sit down please. Now then, any problems since last time? It's good to see you keeping these checkups. Some people just don't bother after they leave home, and when something goes wrong there are all sorts of things to put right. How's your mother, by the way? It was America she moved to, wasn't it?"

As usual, Steve had to wait for three or four questions to go past before he could get a word in. "Yes, she's settled down in North Dakota and she's doing fine. I might go over to see her at Christmas. My teeth are OK, too, but I wouldn't want to miss anything that needs looking at."

"A fine attitude. Now then, lie down and open up."

Steve looked up at the light. "That's new, isn't it? The old one was a different colour."

"That's right, very observant! This one's a new low-voltage design, much more reliable and brighter too. I don't think anyone else has noticed. Open wide."

The nurse hooked in some suction, and went to get Steve's notes.

"Three's OK, two's OK, one's OK, one's OK, two's OK, three's OK, filling on four's a little bitty; we'll sort that out..."

Dr Sells continued chanting his litany as Steve noticed, for the first time it seemed, the antiseptic smell, the faint noise of the machinery behind the dentist, the charts on the wall and the rows of dentures on the shelves. He felt the faint scratching inside his head as the dentist probed away. As Steve had forgotten about the appointment, he hadn't given his teeth the customary vigourous pre-checkup brushing and this was apparently noticeable.

"Hello, we haven't been very thorough with your brushing, have we?" Typical quack, though Steve, lapsing into patronising parental tones. Doctor knows best. "Well, there's a cavity just starting on one of your premolars, and a slightly messy filling to tidy up. We'll have a poke around and fix them."

Steve had collected a lot of fillings from a chocolate childhood, and had the memories to match. As various instruments of torture were produced and whined, sucked and scrunched their way around his mouth, he remembered the old fears with a vividness that surprised him. He winced as the drill scoured the cavity, and was very relieved at the instruction to rinse and spit. Strange taste, this pink liquid.

"While I was fixing those teeth, Steve, I spotted something that might be serious. I'd better have a look at it."

This was new. He opened his mouth obediently, and became more apprehensive as Dr Sell's usual banter failed to intersperse his dental deliberations. Finally the dentist stood up, and Steve closed his mouth.

"One of your molars is misplaced - I don't know why I didn't catch it before, but there you go. Normally I'd leave it, as it's been there for years without causing any problems, but there are signs that you've got some more teeth coming through underneath."

"Eh? You mean I'm teething?"

"No, not quite. It's not uncommon for some people to have a third set of teeth at some time during their lives, and you might be one of them. In any case, I should really get that molar out otherwise it could be very bad for your jaw. It's not really fair that you should have to have a tooth pulled, since you're one of my better patients, but it's a good thing I caught it. Gas or needle?"

He means it, Steve thought. He hadn't had a tooth out before, and the prospect frightened him. Adrenalin started to seep into his blood stream. His heart speeded up, but in his brain the new mechanisms fired up and channelled the stream of his senses into the almost infinite capacity of the revamped memory.

"Oh, gas I think. Is it dangerous?"

"No, not very." Oh, how reassuring, what soothing Weasel words.

"Is the needle safer?"

"There's nothing to worry about with either method. But the gas hurts less."

"Fine. Will it take long?"

"About half an hour, and you should be OK within the hour. Not driving, are you?"

"I walked here."

"No problems then. You might find things a bit fuzzy for a while, but it wears off."

Steve remembered something Emily had said, and for the first time felt sadness for a thing which had never happened.

"Will I dream?"

"Hard to day. Some people do, but most don't."

The nurse had been tinkering with a mess of tubes and cylinders, and brought it to the side of the Chair. While she prepared a tray of gleaming steel instruments, some of which Steve thought would look more in keeping in his local garage, Dr Sells continued his spiel.

"Now then, I'll want you to breath deeply from the mask while counting to ten. You won't get past about seven, but you won't notice that. Ready, Sandra?"

The nurse passed over a facemask, which the dentist placed over Steve's mouth.

"Righty-ho - start breathing and counting. Sweet dreams!"

Here we go, then. One... suck... two... blow... three... suck... four... blow... hmmm, this is quite pleasant... where was I... teeth...

In the surgery, the dentist checked Steve's pulse, eyes and respiration. Satisifed that his patient was well under, he gave him a few seconds more and started to prepare for oral excavation.

Back at the office, Jill wanted to know what Emily was finding so funny. Emily merely giggled, and carried on sorting the post. All that day, she'd be in high spirits, surprising those who were used to her normal sarcastic mood. To those who asked why, she'd reply only that 'Life's a gas, isn't it?'

Chapter 3

Teeth... five... jive.. on the third stroke... hey, why aren't I under yet? Better warn the Weasel not to start pulling just yet. Steve opened his eyes.

If this is dreaming, thought Steve, I haven't missed much. The view reminded him of Dartmoor, where he used to spend the school holidays camping and walking. Only this place was flat for miles, with no inviting tors to clamber up or run down. Behind him the plain stretched out as far as he could see, so for want of anything better to do he started to walk towards the mountains. After a few minutes, he looked as his watch. Or he tried to, but on raising his arm all he saw was a bare wrist. He was greatly troubled. It wasn't so much the lack of a watch that bothered him, nor the fact that the rest of his body was, on inspection, entirely bare, but the troublesome actuality that the body in question wasn't the same one he'd grown up in. In fact, it was borderline as to whether it was Homo Sapiens or not, what with the long hair on the legs and the excessive number of flattened toes. The blue colour didn't help either.

For some reason, he calmed down. Out of curiosity, he tried to yell out "Anyone there?" and was intrigued by the guttural explosion that forced its way out of his mouth, past his fangs and into the leaden air. Fangs. Hmmm. That would startle the good Doctor. He realised with some surprise that he must still be in the Chair, with Dr Sells tapping away like a sculptor producing a miniature statue out of a chip of marble.

He was vaguely uncomfortable about the fact that he'd forgotten so easily who he really was, and tried to shut his eyes to block out the flat dullness of wherever he was. And was gripped by the vertigo as he had been back in his bedroom. This time he got the impression of falling down a well by starlight; a fast fading sprinkling of light and the infinite void waiting...

The landscape looked much more inviting after that. If this was a gas-induced dream he'd sit it out. Half an hour wasn't so long. But it felt like much more than that by the time he decided to get up and explore some more. Maybe his sense of time had gone the way of his skin colour. And, for that matter, the rest of his body, which had acquired several disquietening features which would surprise any osteopath, ear, nose and throat specialist or proctologist. Not that there seemed to be anybody (indeed, any body) else in the place, although once he caught what seemed to be a flash of motion in the sky. He squinted up into the grey light - the shapes that had sped by looked more like fish than birds; he must have been dreaming. That thought made him laugh.

He wandered over to one of the boulders, with the vague intention of climbing up it and looking for something - anything - on the horizon. The surface caught his eyes; like granite it was composed of a myriad tiny facets of crystal, white, orange, black, grey. Unlike granite some of these were quite large, and faintly grooved. These bigger lumps were uniformly white, and they puzzled him. It wasn't until he came across one that was protruding from the rest of the rock, pure white with a blunt point, that he twigged.

Teeth. The rocks were granite, he was sure of that from the mica, feldspar and quartz he recognised - any Dartmoor bog trotter knew granite as the city dwellers recognised concrete - but with an uneven sprinkling of teeth stirred in, like peanuts in a chocolate bar. Again, he thought of the Weasel's constant invectives against refined sugar when he was young; again reminded himself that somewhere his real body was supine and slightly more gummy.

But granite couldn't have teeth in it. Long-distant school geography lessons sprang to mind. Born of elementary fire, hot lava from the earth's core slowly cooling under tremendous pressure with crystals of hard rock forming over centuries, any organic matter would be fried, powdered and assimilated in minutes. It was, he reminded himself, a dream. One which would offend doctors, geologists and dentists in equal measure, but still a dream.

It had to have something to do with being in just such a dream, he thought, but he felt curiously elated. He felt plain curious too - he was looking forward to the next discovery, the next fact to fall out of this strange place. Again, he felt a little disquiet about the ease with which he'd forgotten about his real status as an office worker in Plymouth, but then that place had its fair share of grey skies and boredom too.

He hunted around in the grass until he found a small lump of rock. Odd - he looked around, the scattering of the stuff was fairly even as far as he could see - what on earth (or wherever, he reminded himself) could have caused this place to be like this. He imagined great glaciers slowly melting, dropping rocks as they retreated down the vast gouge they in earlier youth had carved, but that wouldn't explain the flatness of the place. Glaciated valleys - once more, those geography lessons with Rolly Jones surfaced after a decade submerged - were U-shaped. This was plain plane.

This blue and hairy body must belong to a blue and hairy geologist, he thought. He raised the rock above his head, and brought it down hard on the large boulder he'd been examining. The shock jarred his hand, but cracked off a small amount of the boulder's surface. He looked at the spray of chips that littered the grass. They were sharp, like flakes from the surface of a choc ice. The image of an ice cream, he couldn't remember the name, with small fragments of nut in the hard chocolate layer around the soft cream inside, came to mind, and on a whim he nibbled at one of the chips with his recently-enlarged canines. It tasted like a rock.

He looked at the place on the boulder where the chips came from, expecting to see more of the same, perhaps a little more colourful and sharp. Instead he saw a smooth skin, black as the night, underneath what must have just been a shell of toothed rock. He prodded it with one ridiculously long finger (without a fingernail; for a moment he couldn't decide whether it was sillier to have a finger without a fingernail or one with - why did humans have fingernails anyway? He resolved to find out when he was back in the real- he nearly thought other - world) and it gave way a little, like the skin on a dead pig.

Down at his feet, he found a particularly long shard of rock skin. With a roar he jabbed it into the gap on the boulder as hard as he could. This was, he discovered, very hard, and the skin broke. A gush of cold brown liquid shot out and over his - his? - body. He stood there for a moment, surprised, as the sticky coolness trickled down, matting the fine hair which covered him. He poked the same finger into the new gash, expecting to find a void. Instead he encountered a soft, sludgy gunk. It was very cold.

He pulled his finger out (for some reason, an image of his boss came to mind) startled by the unexpected feelings. Again on an impulse, he licked the finger. Chocolate ice cream. He pulled at the rock shell around the gap, removing scabs of the stuff and widening the hole until he could get a fist in. One part of his mind stood back, aghast, as a feeding frenzy took over and he pulled, tugged, hit at the shell, reducing it to fragments and revealing an interior entirely composed of ice cream. With a whoop, he started to scoop the stuff into his mouth, not minding whether it ran down his chin, onto his chest, caking him with stickyness.

"No. Chocolate. No chocolate. Bad for the teeth"

Eh? Where did the voice come from? He looked up, and realised that he was cold, shivering, and standing in a spreading puddle of molten ice cream. He was very, very messy.

"It'll ruin your teeth. Not good at all".

Was that - that was the Weasel. "Steve, you mustn't eat so much chocolate. Steve, you have to wake up to the fact that your teeth must last you the rest of your life. Steve, wake up. Steve!"

He shook his head, and suddenly felt very cold indeed. The grey of the sky lightened to orange, to white and he shivered.

"Steve, wake up!"

He blinked, and felt the ground somersault like a funfair ride. He tumbled, was lying down. He was on the couch, looking up at Dr Sells.

"Steve, can you hear me?"

"Uh" why was his mouth so horrible? "yeah. Yes, I can hear you. I've been dreaming, I think"

"Don't talk. Take deep breaths. Do you feel OK?"

Stupid dentist. How can I tell you if I can't talk? "Uhuh".

"Good. I hit an artery, though what it was doing there I don't know, and we had a bit of an emergnecy. You're OK, though, not too much blood lost, and I've called an ambulance just in case. Ruined your clothes though - I'm sorry."

His head spun. He tried to sit up, and in the couple of seconds before he collapsed back to the Chair he saw a blood-soaked body. At least it had pink hands.

Chapter 4

The doctors at Freedom Fields Hospital weren't concerned with his dream. "Happens all the time, old man" one particularly young one said "You're dreaming about walking through a town when a fire engine goes past, bell ringing like billy-oh. You wake up, and the alarm clock's going nineteen to the dozen. Brain's made the connection, you see."

Apart from the fact that he'd never owned an alarm clock with a bell, and suspected that the doctor had been watching too many Sunday afternoon wartime films, Steve saw. It had been a particularly vivid dream, but perhaps everyone dreamed like that under gas. He'd been given two pints of blood, which gave the lie to Dr Sells' soothing words, and was under observation for the rest of the day. According to the ward sister, he'd be out by seven since they needed the bed and he was young enough to survive "seeing what you young people do to yourselves nothing like this should worry you" by himself.

The tooth had been removed, and in its place was a lump of surgical padding. Steve explored it with his tongue, it seemed much large and ten times rougher than the tooth it replaced but he expected that was just the unfamiliarity and weirdness of the pad. Again he felt strange, he wasn't used to such ideas and didn't know where they came from. That they might come from himself seemed impossible.

The young doctor came back. "How are we doing?" "I'm feeling OK." He took Steve's blood pressure and pulse rate. "I think you'll be OK for this evening, but take it easy for the next week or so".

"Er, Doctor?"

"Yes?"

"I'm still worried by the dream I had."

The doctor sat down on the bed, and carefully placed his clipboard on the sheets before looking, seriously and with obvious intent, at Steve.

"We all have dreams, old man."

"No, I don't get dreams, apart from this time. It was so real, like being there, only I've never been anywhere like that before. Do you think it could have been the gas?"

"That's possible. It's really nothing to worry about, though. It's been quite a traumatic experience for you. Look, if the dreams come back or you're still worried about things a week from now I can recommend a friend of mine who should sort you out."

"He's a doctor too?"

"Yes, but not a blood and guts man like me. He's a psychoanalyst."

"Um... thanks. I think."

The doctor laughed "Nobody's saying you're anything but sane. It's just if you're troubled by this thing I don't know anyone better. He's especially good on dreams. Wrote a book about them a while back, I think he's quite famous."

"Among shrinks."

"Yes, I suppose. Look, hold on a minute."

The doctor scribbled out a name and phone number on his pad, and tore off the sheet. "Here you go. If you do give him a call, tell him Dr Chapman sent you, OK?"

"Thanks, mate. I hope I don't, if you see what I mean."

"Right. Anything else?" And as there was nothing else, the doctor left.

He caught the bus home. Experimentally probing the top of the wadding, he decided that soup and stuff would be on the menu for the next week. That night he slept soundly, for the last time, as the day's happenings were sorted and stored. For later.

Chapter 4 of "Weird Dreams" begins with Steve waking up in the hospital after his dentist appointment. He discusses the strange dream he had with the young doctor, who suggests that it might be the effect of the gas Steve received during the dental procedure. The doctor provides Steve with the phone number of a psychoanalyst friend should he need someone to talk to about his strange and vivid dreams. After leaving the hospital, Steve goes home and sleeps soundly but ominously notes that this is the last time he will experience such peaceful sleep.

The chapter serves as a transition point between Steve's strange dream and the events that will follow in the story. It establishes the fact that he is starting
